clean_story:
"Teamwork in the wild. Predators hunt together. "

The term cooperative hunting describes when animals work in groups to catch prey—like a well-practiced sports team, but with claws and strategy.


Wolves are the classic example.

They don’t just chase—they cut off escape routes, using speed and numbers to exhaust prey like elk or bison.

One study in Yellowstone showed wolves succeed 14% of the time alone, but 42% in packs.


Lions use brute force and stealth.

Females spread out in a half-circle, then ambush zebras, forcing them toward hidden males.

Their success rate jumps from 20% solo to 30%+ in groups.


Even orcas coordinate.

Some pods create waves to wash seals off ice floes.

Others use tail slaps to stun fish, making them easier to grab.


The key? Roles, not chaos.

Each member has a job—flusher, chaser, ambusher—like players in a play.

Failure means hunger. Success means survival.


Three related subjects are animal communication signals, predator-prey arms races, and human hunting partnerships.
